node.text: Faced with the challenges of building on an island, a New York–based family embraces the benefits of prefab design with a custom Axiom timber home by @turkeldesign.

node.title: This Inviting Prefab Home in Martha’s Vineyard Takes Cues From Nature

node.text:
Dubbed the Zen Den, this serene home by Whitney Brown and Carlos Naude, the creative duo behind @workingholidaystudio, is brightened with an infusion of natural light and now serves as the couple’s personal residence and design showroom.
-
Check out @workingholidayspaces to see more of Whitney and Carlos’ work.

node.text:
Though smack dab in the middle of Los Angeles’ vibrant East Side, this home feels like a secret hideaway. Steps from a street lined with apartment buildings, modest older homes, and commercial warehouses, the single-level house, with just one window on the front facade, looks inward, becoming more open as you move through it to the surprisingly lush backyard. “We wanted to explore indoor/outdoor living in a different way,” says owner Mark Motonaga of @rioshome, who renovated the 1920s-era home with his partner, artist Guy Clouse. Read the complete feature on Atwater Hideaway, nominated in this year’s Dwell Design Awards, when you visit dwell.com/design-awards
–
Architecture by @rios.imagines
Photos by @hunterkerhart
Lighting Design by @esquared_lighting
Pool Fabrication by @johncrystalpools
Sofa and Custom Four-Poster Bed by @stephenkenn
Custom Ceramic Coffee Tables by @benmedansky
Dining Table by @crofthousela
Credenza by @kleinagency
Dining Chairs by @markalbrechtstudio
Bathroom Fixtures by @pirch
#moderndesign #modernarchitecture #landscapedesign #landscapearchitecture #garden #secretgarden #bungalow #renovation #remodel #livingroom #bedroomdesign #indooroutdoorliving #interiordesign

node.title: A Boxy Los Angeles Bungalow Conceals a Secret Garden

node.text:
Architect Steven Ehrlich of @eyrcarchitects reflects on his experiences in Africa and Japan to build a sustainable, ever-changing home in Los Angeles. See more at Dwell.com/escapes
—
#dwellescapes #dwellxgenesis #losangeles #gv80 #genesisusa #moderndesign #modernarchitecture #interiordesign #interiorarchitecture #landscapedesign

node.title: An Architect’s Venice Home Draws Inspiration From Around the World

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Dwell on September 15, 2021. May be an image of outdoors and brick wall.

node.text:
Well, this is probably the nicest fortress we’ve seen in a while. Echoing the traditional Portuguese alcáçova—an ancient form of defensive settlement found across the Mediterranean—the holiday home is a striking form within the arid landscape of cork trees and cow herds. “We were inspired by the concept of a house which is a fortress with a larger inner court; a trace of white chalk in the landscape,” says architect Paulo Martins-Barata, founding partner of Lisbon-based practice @promontorio.arch. “The Alentejo landscape, and this mountain in particular, is harsh, even desolate, but beautiful and poetic at the same time. It evokes a kind of existential solitude.” In contrast to the home’s blunt exterior, the owners’ aim was to create a welcoming space that could easily host large groups. "This house is made for fun, for joy, to party, and to join family and friends," says Martins-Barata. "Its interior and exterior criss-cross at all times, with everybody passing through the vortex of the house, which unsurprisingly is the kitchen." Take the full tour of Casa da Volta, or “Home of the Return,” at the link in bio.
–
Photos by @luisviegasphotography
Story by @mandikeighran
#moderndesign #modernarchitecture #interiordesign #interiorarchitecture #portugal #portuguesearchitecture #portuguesedesign #holidayhome #vacationhome #desertliving #desertdesign #desertlandscaping #courtyard #gravel #cacti #indooroutdoor

node.text:
This Brazilian home is a real two-for-one situation. Designed by architect Tito Ficarelli for his family, the home in São Paulo merges two distinct Brazilian architectural styles: while the facade riffs on the city’s tough-and-ready ad hoc influences, it is also defined by a cast-in-place concrete structure that nods to a tradition of tropical brutalism. The contrasting frame makes for a favela-meets-bourgeouisie moment that mirrors its interiors, where private quarters sit below the social spaces on the main floor. Tito calls it an “upside down house,” referencing a style more popular in the early 20th century. “It’s a functional home for our family, but it’s also a space where the public is invited in to see art exhibitions or site-specific performances.” See how Sunset House’s brutalist form opens up to casual and formal spaces alike when you try Dwell+ at the link in bio.
–
Photos by @joaodmorgado
Architecture by @arkitito
Landscape Design by @livthenature

node.text:
This home in Lithuania brings a whole new meaning to being one with nature. With a radical bermed design by architects Gabrielé Ubarevičiūtė and Giedrius Mamavicius, cofounders of architecture firm @after_party.eu, the structure takes a first step in mediating the relationship between architecture and the landscape within a previously undeveloped tract. “When we first visited the area, there were no houses around, only a blossoming meadow filled with bees and little insects,” remembers Ubarevičiūtė. “Knowing that it would turn into a neighborhood in the future, our main aim was to preserve what was already there and find ways to compensate for our intrusion.” To create a residence with sensitivity toward the site, the designers implemented a green roof that touches down fully on both sides of a terrace just outside the living room. “It creates a feeling of solitude and framing life within nature as if it’s a living room under an open sky,” says Ubarevičiūtė. Take a stroll through, over, and under the home—dubbed the House and the River—at the link in bio.
–
Photos by @giedrius.mamavicius 
Story by @desert.ren

node.text:
A flea market find kicked off the design process for this Cape Town home. Inspired by the patinated, exposed-brick designs in the book on 1970s buildings, owners Robyn and Clint Campbell showed the pages to their friend, architect Michael Lumby of @michael_lumby_architecture, who was otherwise given carte blanche to design the home. “Clint gave me a simple brief,” says Lumby. “Three bedrooms, two bathrooms, and a living area.” Lumby delivered a three-floor, 1,520-square-foot brick building that stands like a beacon—its curves nodding to the Art Deco heritage found in the neighborhood of Vredehoek where it stands. “The theme was to invest in craftsmanship and custom detailing rather than expensive finishing and materials,” Lumby says. One detail, a bathroom sink with an angled pane where water runs into the garden, is case in point. “If you give someone the chance to use their voice,” says Clint, who speaks from experience as a creative director, “they tend to really shine.” Tour the ‘70s-inspired Cape Town home when you try Dwell+ at the link in bio.
–
Photos by @elsa47 
Story by @tiffany_jow

node.text:
One couple didn’t have to search too far for an architect to help them with their Victorian revamp. Kate and Gary Westlake turned to Kate’s brother, Ben Minifie of @minifiearchitects, to help them reorient the home for their growing family. After extending the bedrooms of the teenage children—offering them better lighting and a shared bathroom, along with storage space and study areas—Minifie turned his focus to the family’s shared spaces on the main floor. By reorganizing the floorplan, the family gained a snug TV room and guest bedroom, all clad in plywood. An oriel window adds further coziness to the space as “the perfect place to sit and read a book,” says Gary. The extensive use of timber not only unifies the interior but also reaches outside, wrapping around a backyard to a new outbuilding that houses a home office, bar, and DJ area. Through the reno, the family has fallen in love with their home again. "How we use the house has changed massively," says Gary. "All of a sudden, partly due to lockdown but also because we now have all this well-designed space, we are spending more quality time together as a family." Take the full tour of the Blackheath House at the link in bio.
–
Photos by @willscottphoto
Story by Sophie Vening

node.text:
Long live California modernism. Perched below the Griffith Observatory and overlooking Hollywood is a lush lot crowned with four towering olive trees and a 1965 home designed by modernist architect Craig Ellwood. When a young couple purchased the home in 2018, it needed substantial work. For a historic restoration, they called on @woods_dangaran, a local firm fluent in modernist history. While keeping original components like the home’s linear shape, open plan, and expansive windows, the team meticulously restored the home. “It was important to us to keep the structure because it really was classic Ellwood,” says Joe Dangaran, one of the firm’s cofounders. One of the most striking features is the original koi pond—a feature deemed so essential that its preservation was a condition of escrow—that’s now crossed via a bridge that leads to a lap pool, perhaps the biggest intervention on the property. Throughout the restoration, a common phrase came to mind for Dangaran: “What would Craig Ellwood have done?” Take the full tour of the glorious Moore House Restoration at the link in bio.
–

node.text:
The jet-black home in Australia keeps its cool in more ways than one. Designed by Melbourne-based firm @editionoffice for a client dreaming of a peaceful retreat, the structure shows tranquility done right. “Discussions with the client focused upon providing a home as sanctuary—an elemental respite from a high-pressure professional life,” say the architects. Using a material palette of black wood and darkly pigmented concrete, the home wraps around a two-story opening that spotlights a verdant courtyard of ferns. On its east side—looking out at never-ending landscapes—the home holds two small bedrooms and a bathroom, along with a larger en suite with a private terrace. A narrow subterranean pool runs through the home, reflecting the horizon, and aims to resemble a natural swimming hole. Not only is the home an exquisite example of minimal design with a big impact, it’s also extremely functional in its setting. The house solely relies on cross ventilation, cooling by the pool before flowing up through the fern garden. To see more of the Federal House, hit the link in bio.
–
Photos by @benhoskingphotographer
Story by @sonia_zhur
Builder & General Contractor @sjreynoldsconstructions

node.text:
Blink and you might miss the subtle, upcycled beauty of this London flat. Alessia Mosci—creative director and co-owner of architecture and interiors practice @mwaiarchitects—had a guiding principle while heading into her remodel: resourceful constraint. “There is a tendency to just take everything out and start fresh,” Alessia says. “But we tried to work with the building whilst making the changes we wanted.” The canvas Alessia chose for her project was a 1903 Edwardian terrace building, converted into an apartment in the ‘70s, that yielded plenty of reusable materials and a few surprises. While exploring the space, the designer found a sealed-off loft/storage area upstairs, which she converted into an en suite. She also had the original floorboards removed, restored, and reinstalled under a rebuilt roof that now features generous skylights. Even the marble in the kitchen—left over from a past client—speaks to Alessia’s adaptation to preexisting materials. “It’s good to experiment,” says Alessia, reflecting on her finished home. “And to follow your instincts.” Take the full tour of her resourceful renovation, aptly named an Upcycled Project, when you try Dwell+ at the link in bio.
–
Photos by @_billybolton
Story by @melissadalton_pdx

node.text:
Once the sun goes down, this prefab home does a pretty neat trick. The team over at Rotterdam-based @orangearchitectsnl designed the roughly 970-square-foot space with a focus on social spaces, but the home’s true glory lies in its flexibility. By day, the house flexes it’s indoor/outdoor design through floor-to-ceiling windows and doors that look out to the bucolic setting of Texel, an island in the Netherlands. To maintain privacy once the sun falls, the owners can turn wooden panels on the first level 90 degrees to transform the living space into a private room for sleeping. The library also becomes a full-size bedroom, while the hidden shower and sink convert into an en suite bathroom. More than just a novelty, the innovative design continues to delight the homeowners. "It’s nice to see that Holiday Home—as compact as it is—feels comfortable and familiar to our client but also continues to surprise, inspire, and enchant them every day," shares Patrick Meijers, one of the firm’s partners. Take a look through the entire Holiday Home at the link in bio.
–
Photos by @svd_fotografie

node.text:
After five years in a quaint bungalow-style home, one young family had outgrown their footprint and were ready for an upgrade. For their Hermosa Beach renovation, Mardi and Anton Watts turned to @ras_a.studio, who, after a closer look, determined a reno on the tight lot wasn’t going to cut it. The firm instead designed this new two-story home, an airy stack of wood-slatted boxes, complementing both the area’s low-slung midcentury bungalows and its taller, more recent developments. The challenge laid in making the most square footage while meeting the city’s car-conscious zoning requirements. “How do we get enough space on the ground floor when Hermosa Beach dictates you need a two-car garage,” principal architect Robert Sweet recalls thinking. With a blessing from the city planning department, a mechanical lift that stacks one car atop the other was installed, reserving more square footage for the living areas. See how the Hermosa Beach home came together when you try Dwell+ at the link in bio.
–
Photos by @joefletcherphoto
Story by @atthecrosswalk

node.text:
Despite its tiny footprint, Olive—an aptly named green houseboat—is fully equipped for a modern lifestyle. The 59-foot floating abode was designed in 2019 by its architect owners, and currently sits on Regents Canal in London. While extremely adorable, the home’s design is equally practical. It’s “a contemporary and timeless vessel in harmony with her fluvial surroundings,” notes @aucoot. They’re not wrong: past the sofa and two-seater dining table is a relatively large kitchen with oak-faced cabinets, along with a counter-to-ceiling backsplash that adds a sense of openness to the space. The opposite side of the boat holds the bedroom, along with a bathroom complete with an eco-friendly composting toilet. There’s even a charming outdoor seating area on the bow that extends a warm welcome through glass doors. Best of all, the houseboat is looking for new owners. Head to the link in bio to see more of the quaint home, currently listed for £125,000.
–
Photos Courtesy of @aucoot

node.text:
When the architects at ATOMAA first approached this crumbling home in the Italian Alps, it was in pretty rough shape. But its agrarian heritage and abundance of reusable materials were undeniable, guiding a contemporary renovation that honors the past. The 1,530-square-foot home—dubbed House Cinsc—carefully balances authenticity with modern intervention, making it one family’s perfect retreat amid the towering peaks of Varzo, Italy. With the help of local artisans, Milan-based @atomaa.eu restored the exterior using stones from the original structure. The rugged shell now houses an unadorned yet welcoming space from which to observe the surrounding landscape. Inside, an entirely wooden core traces the shape of the stone exterior and lends the home warmth within “a context strongly characterized by stone,” as the ATOMAA team describes it. Just as intended, the restored home is rigorous and minimal, yet comfortably rustic. Perhaps more importantly, its neighboring rock formations and idyllic pastures remain untouched. Take the full tour of House Cinsc at the link in bio.
–
Photos by @albertostrada
Story by Grace Bernard
